ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Economic analysis, various concepts of contract, tort, and criminal law
Economic analysis of law

Abstract and broad foundation of legal principles-mainly those contained in the book Foundations of Economic Analysis of Law by Stephen Shavell. This book is basically the entire class, so I would recommend taking a look and seeing if it interests you before deciding to take this course.
Law and legal theory surrounding economic cost benefit analyses of legal terminologies. Discussions of morality and uses of utility maximization for approaches to legal practice.

The course was a good introduction to some topics in law such as property law, tort law, etc. If you think you would be interested in law school, I'd recommend the class to get a glimpse of some of the content.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor could frame discussions a bit more and add personal insight.

I felt that the discussion each week was rather poorly run, there were many times where Professor Landis would repeat questions we already discussed and would leave the room in an awkward silence. There was also an excessive amount of reading, with 60-100 page legal journal articles assigned that would prompt maybe one question in the subsequent class period, and so by the end of the semester it seemed like a waste of time to read them.
Fewer readings and more opportunities for feedback
more structured discussions please

It very much pains me to write this, but I think the real weakness in the course has to do with the professor. Professor Landis is very kind, yet I think in his retirement and age he is very divorced from the actual class itself, and he maintained a very hands-off approach to the entire course. Everything was uncertainexpectations in class, assignments that needed to be completed, and grades. Even now as I write this, I have literally no idea what my grade will be, as we received no feedback in the entire course, and only received grades for our midterms in the last ~2 weeks of class. The discussion is entirely led by the classentirely. When the class would go off on interesting tangents, it would be interesting, but otherwise it would usually be dull and repetitive points made by the same people while the majority of the class sat silent. While I genuinely found the Shavell book to be interesting (and reading it did teach me about some foundational aspects of economic principles in law), I learned next to nothing in the class itself.

Strength of this course was the foundational book on which it is based is excellent and incredibly informative. Weakness is that discussion is not particularly well facilitated ted and often fell flat as there was little to no input other than a few series of pre-written questions offered by the instructor.

The course really only follow Steven Shavell's book and doesn't really stray from the content from there. If you find his book interesting then this course is for you, if not then do not take it. Prof. Landis is a nice professor who means well, but not necessarily the best seminar or discussion leader (he asks very repetitive questions and does not engage very much in students' answers). The course is kind of all over the place (due dates changed from what was on the syllabus, he got rid of most of our papers with little notice, the exam was a different length than previously promised, etc.) but was very manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For someone who is looking for a discussion group about economic analyses of law, this class is pretty good. For someone who wants to receive a lot of guidance from the Professor, this class is not one to take.

I would not recommend this course. I personally enjoyed reading Shavell, who generally speaking does a good job of using economic concepts to examine legal statutes, but the course itself was not well run and not particularly interesting.
Good for anyone interested in Econ and law. Good class for EPE
not unless you are genuinely interested in law
No.
If you are interested in the topic yes but only if you are willing to be an active participant in discussion.

Take it if you like long discussions about cost benefit of a myriad of different little things. Be sure to email Prof. Landis about your enrollment in the course because he may miss your application. Enroll and email as early as possible.
If you want a chill EPE advanced seminar then definitely take it but I think there may be other seminars that are more fulfilling than this one.
